i’m going for huge change in my code like changes in ui and many other features, can any one advice me the best way to manage my codebase in a new branch?

<@U1T13H6S3>: try to keep the changes smaller and modular. Probably you’ll clone your main branch and then start developing on it. Nothing better than having tests (unit and functional) for every pull request. Maintain a changelog so that it’s easier to know what happened last time and easier to track if something breaks.

it says " com.google.android.gms libraries must use the exact same version specification (mixing versions can lead to runtime crashes). Found versions 8.4.0, 8.3.0. im not using google
play services measurment 8.3 anywhere in my project
yes you are lol
but I added butterKnife recently
dependencies have dependencies

run `./gradlew :<modulename>:dependencies`

For most projects that ends up being `./gradlew :mobile:dependencies`
be aware that you can find other useful commands on your projects via `./gradlew -q tasks —all`
you usually don’t need the —all flag though but sometimes you do
<@U055GGAHS>: :taco: :nutella:
i changed the order of dependencies moved all google dependencies to the end, now it is working
:thinking_face: that’s not how that works
but glad you fixed your problem, more likely cache broke and changing your build file cleared the bad cache or something
android studio is notoriously buggy with FS changes due to fsnotifier in particular that can surface in weird errors like that.
our team is always having to restart/clear cached/stop gradle
we were just dealing with it this morning so i though i’d share here.
yeah it happens pretty often
someone familiar with android MVP architechture?
what about it?
ofc, y?
when a user clicks in a fragment on a button and it should change the fragment afterwards. the click goes to the presenter and then?.where do you handle the fragment change?
imo, you handle that in the view
that’s what i don’t like actually
why? it’s part of the platform, so the part tied to the platform should handle it
view can forward it to a router if you have something like that
with view you mean the fragment and not the activity right?
it can be fragment, activity, custom view, whatever implements your view interface
or you can have a router/navigation/parent activity interface and you inject it into your presenter and call it’s method
ya that was my first idea
ok thanks!

>>>Hello Google Play Developer, 

At Google I/O 2016, we announced that Google Play would be launching on Chromebooks. As an Android developer, your apps will soon be compatible with Chromebooks. Here’s how you can improve the Chromebook experience for your Android apps:

Begin by reviewing the I/O session - “Bring your Android App to Chromebooks”
Read this Android Developers Help Center article to learn how to optimize your Android apps for Chromebooks.
Update the AndroidManifest.xml and set touchscreen as not required if you want to reach customers on non-touchscreen Chromebooks.
Learn how to manage your app's compatible devices and more about Chrome OS Device Support for Apps.

No action is required, but we recommend the steps above to best position your app for the millions of potential customers using Chromebooks.
Thanks for supporting Google Play,
The Google Play Team

I would say that it perfectly fits your situation. You get compilation safety with enums as well as generated request code
true..
Personally, whenever I get the chance to wrap Androids shitty internal in something nicer I just do it because the performance hit is almost never noticeable

But, this will add an extra step to the checking logic. You will need to acquire the enum based on the requestCode that was returned. So you would need a `fromRequestCode` method inside the `MyRequestCodes` class where you would basically move the `if` in there and match the code received to the appropriate enum
so at that point it might prove a bit useless to do
but
I would argue that you can put the functionality that should happen at each code *inside* the enum
and voila you have created a state machine

methods are not considered constants
`public static final` is not the same thing as constant

it infers runtime constant but not necessarily compile time constant.

For instance
`public static final Date DATE = new Date()`

This would never be a ‘constant’ and varies depending on the initial creation of the process

/**

attachments.title: Tracks the number of calories consumed though out the day.
attachments.text: Tracks the number of calories a person consumes in a given meal it has helper method to get the day's total. The check method Tries to find any duplicate meals within the given list. The assumption...
attachments.fallback: Tracks the number of calories consumed though out the day.

text:
DINER == place where you eat
DINNER == meal :slightly_smiling_face:
DINERO == money
DINAR = yugoslavian money
don’t use exceptions as flow control
your method names are terrible tbh
you should be able to tell what check does just by looking at the method name
checkForDuplicateMeals(); but it shouldn’t be necessary if you were just adding meals to a hashset
you need to design this better if you want to use it inside an app

could you point me in the right direction as far as  a proper design is concerned ? where am I making the mistake what are some other alternatives. I'd like to learn from you. I'm an entry level Android dev  with about 1 year under my belt.

1. User won’t add all meals at once, but one by one, so you need to design your system akin to that
2. Don’t use exceptions as flow control
3. Use HashSet - it was made for sets of unique items
4. This would mean you just maintain 1 set and add meals to it. Calorie calculation would be iterating over and summing, or you could maintain a complete sum in a specific number you increment on adding a meal
